Graphical abstract CoP and Co2P were prepared by temperature-programmed reduction of the mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3 with stoichiometric P/Co ratios, but their surfaces were still enriched in phosphorus. Based on the product distributions of the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT), 1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-dibenzothiophene (TH-DBT), and 1,2,3,4,4a,9b-hexahydro-dibenzothiophene (HH-DBT), a reaction network of DBT HDS was proposed and the mechanisms of the cleavage of different CS bonds in DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates were discussed. CoP was much more active and more nitrogen-tolerant than Co2P, which make it a promising HDS catalyst. The HDS reactions over CoP and Co2P followed a pseudo-first-order kinetics and a pseudo-zero-order kinetics, respectively. Piperidine strongly inhibited the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions and the direct desulfurization of DBT, but its inhibition on the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT were less pronounced. The active surfaces of CoP and Co2P in HDS reactions can be cobalt phosphosulfide phases. Keywords Hydrodesulfurization Dibenzothiophene Hydrogenated intermediates CoP Co2P Piperidine 1 Introduction The metal-rich transition-metal phosphides (metal/phosphorus > l) and monophosphides (metal/phosphorus = l) possess metallic character [1], and thus have drawn attention in many reactions catalyzed by metals. They have proved to be active in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) reactions [2,3]. The intrinsic HDS and HDN activities of the transition-metal phosphides are comparable or much higher than the conventional sulfide catalysts [1,4,5]. In recent years, they were also found to be promising for a variety of important reactions like hydrogenation [6], hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [7], hydrogen evolution [8,9], oxygen reduction [10,11], methanol oxidation [12], and methanol synthesis from CO and CO2 [13], as well as anode materials for lithium ion battery [14]. The reported phosphide HDS catalysts can be mainly categorized into two classes, the Group VIB transition-metal phosphides (e.g. MoP and WP) and the Group VIII transition-metal phosphides (e.g. nickel, cobalt, iron, and palladium phosphides). These phosphides are covalent compounds, in which the electron density is shared between the metal and phosphorus atoms [15]. Therefore, they usually occur with many stoichiometries and structures. Their catalytic properties depend greatly on their compositions and structures. For example, Ni2P crystallizes in a hexagonal structure (space group P 6 ¯ 2m), and is the most active catalyst among the nickel phosphides for simultaneous HDS and HDN reactions [5]. The body-centered tetragonal Ni12P5 (space group I4/m) exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability towards the hydrogen evolution reaction in acidic solutions [16,17]. Recently, Yu et al. [7] demonstrated that Ni2P was water-sensitive in aqueous phase HDO of phenol. During the reaction, it was evolutionarily transformed to an amorphous phase and then to Ni5P2 and Ni12P5, and finally to Ni3P at elevated temperatures. The tetragonal Ni3P (space group I-4) showed extraordinary hydrogenation activity at low temperatures and high HDO activity at high temperatures. In the early years of research, it has been realized that Co2P was intrinsically the least active one among the transition-metal phosphides in the HDN of o-propylaniline (Co2P < WP < Ni2P < MoP) [1]. Oyama reported that the activities of the phosphides for the simultaneous HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) and HDN of quinoline at 370 °C and 3.1 MPa followed the order Fe2P < CoP < MoP < WP < Ni2P [5]. Therefore, cobalt phosphides did not receive the same attention as Ni2P, MoP, and WP for the HDS and HDN reactions. Later, Burns et al. [18] demonstrated that the activities of CoxPy/SiO2 catalysts in the HDS of thiophene exhibited a volcano-type trend as a function of the P/Co molar ratio of their oxidic precursors, and the activity of CoP/SiO2 (prepared from a phosphate oxidic precursor having the minimum excess P needed to give phase-pure CoP) was nearly four times as high as that of Co2P/SiO2. The preparation of CoP by the conventional temperature-programmed reduction method from a phosphate precursor is challenging, not only because the reduction of the phosphate precursors has to be carried out at elevated temperatures [19], but also because large excess of phosphorus is needed to obtain phase-pure CoP. Burns et al. [18] showed that the reduction of the phosphate precursor with stoichiometric P/Co ratio (0.5) yielded Co2P/SiO2, whereas the minimum P/Co ratio for the preparation of phase-pure CoP/SiO2 was as high as 1.5. The excess phosphorus usually has strong negative influences on the HDS activities of transition-metal phosphides [18]. Quite a few methods have been developed for the preparation of Ni2P (the other Group VIII transition-metal phosphide) with stoichiometric P/Ni ratio, such as the treatment of nickel or nickel oxide particles with PH3 and H2 [20], the reduction of phosphate precursors in hydrogen plasma [21], the thermal decomposition of a nickel oxide and sodium hypophosphite precursor [22], or the phosphidation of Ni(acac)2 with trioctylphosphine [23]. Nevertheless, as pointed out by Teixeira da Silva et al. [24], these methods have disadvantages that may limit their practical application in the preparation of industrial phosphide catalysts. Additionally, whether these methods are applicable for the preparation of cobalt phosphides still needs to be verified. In 2009, Cecilia et al. [25,26] provided an alternative method for the preparation of supported Ni2P or CoP catalysts, i.e. the temperature-programmed reduction of phosphite-based precursors such as (Ni(HPO3H)2) or (Co(HPO3H)2) in H2, respectively. This method can be carried out at lower reduction temperatures without calcination procedure. The obtained phase-pure CoP catalysts supported on MCM-41, zirconium doped MCM-41, and SiO2 (Cab-osil) all exhibited high activities in the HDS of DBT at high temperatures, which mainly occurred via the direct desulfurization (DDS) route [26]. Nevertheless, the P/Co ratio (2) in these dihydrogenphosphite precursors is much higher than the stoichiometric P/Co ratio of CoP. In other words, phosphorus is still in large excess in the obtained CoP catalyst. In the present work, we found that bulk CoP and Co2P catalysts with stoichiometric P/Co ratios can be prepared by temperature-programmed reduction of the corresponding mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3. This allows an in-depth investigation on the HDS performances of cobalt phosphides. DBT was used as the model sulfur-containing compound because it is one of the most refractory molecules to be hydrodesulfurized. The network of the HDS of DBT is complex (Scheme S1 in the Supplementary Material), and involves several hydrogenated sulfur-containing intermediates like 1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-dibenzothiophene (TH-DBT) and 1,2,3,4,4a,9b-hexahydro-dibenzothiophene (HH-DBT). Therefore, the HDS reactions of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT were all studied so as to gain a full understanding of the HDS of DBT over CoP and Co2P. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Preparation of catalyst precursors The precursors of CoP and Co2P were prepared by dropwise adding respectively 2.07 and 4.13 g cobalt (II) hydroxide (Co(OH)2, Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd.) to a solution of 1.82 g phosphorous acid (H3PO3, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) in 15 mL deionized water while stirring. After continuous stirring for 1 h, the mixtures were dried in an electric blast oven at 80 °C for 12 h to produce the final catalyst precursors. 2.2 HDS activity measurement The HDS reactions were carried out in a stainless-steel tubular reactor (8.0 mm i.d.). The precursor was pelleted, crushed, and sieved to 20–40 mesh. A total of 0.10 g precursor was used for each run. Prior to HDS reaction, the catalyst precursor was transformed into the phosphide phase by in-situ H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) [27]. It was reduced in a 150 mL/min H2 flow at 1.0 MPa by heating from room temperature to 100 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C/min and maintaining this temperature for 1 h, then heated to 500 °C at 3 °C/min and holding at 500 °C for 3 h. After the precursor had been converted to the active phosphide phase, the reactor was cooled to the reaction temperature of 340 °C and the total pressure was increased to 4.0 MPa. The feed consisted of 1 kPa reactant (DBT, TH-DBT, or HH-DBT), 165 kPa decalin (as solvent, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), and about 3.8 MPa H2 both in the absence or presence of 0.25 kPa piperidine (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.). DBT was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd., while TH-DBT and HH-DBT were synthesized following methods described elsewhere [28]. The space–time (or the contact time) calculated based on the catalyst weight was defined as τ = w cat/n feed, where w cat denotes the catalyst weight (g) and n feed the total molar flow to the reactor (mol/min) [29]. The space–time was changed by varying the flow rates of the liquid (from 0.05 to 0.3 mL/min) and the gas simultaneously (from 37.5 to 225 mL/min), while keeping the gas/liquid rate ratio constant at 750 v/v. The reaction products were analyzed off-line by an Agilent-6890N gas chromatograph equipped with an HP-5 column and a hydrogen flame ionization detector. Because 3-phenyl-1-cyclohexene (3-PCHE) and phenylcyclohexane (or cyclohexylbenzene, CHB) cannot be separated by the non-polar HP-5 column, a HP-INNOWax polyethylene glycol column was used to quantify the 1-phenyl-1-cyclohexene (1-PCHE), 3-PCHE, and 4-phenyl-1-cyclohexene (4-PCHE) presented in the desulfurization products [27]. The structures and the acronyms of the main compounds involved in the present work are listed in Table 1 . 2.3 Characterization Before characterization, the CoP and Co2P catalyst samples were prepared under the same conditions used in the in-situ reduction, followed by passivation with 0.5 vol% O2 in Ar. The spent catalysts (after the HDS of DBT) were used directly for the XRD and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements after being flushed with n-heptane and dried with an Ar flow, and they were transferred to the XRD and XPS instruments through air. The XRD patterns of the fresh and spent catalysts were measured on a Rigaku D/Max 2400 diffractometer with nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 100 mA. The compositions of the two fresh cobalt phosphide samples were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, Optima 2000DV). Nitrogen physisorption was performed on a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 analyzer with an absolute accuracy ≤ 0.5%. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken using a Tecnai G220 S-Twin microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the fresh and spent catalysts were obtained with a Thermo ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with a high-resolution double-focusing hemispherical analyzer, using a monochromated Al Kα (1486.6 eV) source. The base pressure before analysis was better than 5 × 10−6 Pa. All the spectra were obtained in a constant analyzer energy mode. A constant pass energy of 20 eV was used for the narrow-scan, while the wide-scan spectra were acquired with a pass energy of 50 eV. The instrument was operated in standard lens mode and the aperture was 0.5 mm diameter. The accuracy of the binding energy values was ±0.05 eV. All binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. The atomic concentrations of different chemical elements were extracted from XPS intensity ratios after proper normalization using atomic sensitivity factors [30]. CO adsorption was carried out using pulsed chemisorption as described elsewhere [31]. About 0.2 g passivated, air-exposed catalyst sample was re-reduced in a H2 flow to remove the passivation layer (80 mL/min flow rate, heating from 25 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and then holding at the final temperature for 1 h). The reactor was then cooled to 30 °C in a flow of H2. An Ar flow at 80 mL/min was used to flush the catalyst for 30 min to achieve an adsorbate-free, reduced catalyst surface. After pretreatment, 113 μL pulses of 2 vol% CO in Ar were injected into a flow of Ar (80 mL/min), and the CO uptake was measured using a TCD detector. CO pulses were repeatedly injected until the response from the detector showed no further CO uptake. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization In the XRD patterns of the fresh catalyst samples (Fig. 1 ), only diffraction lines due to CoP and Co2P phases were observed. The P/Co ratios of CoP and Co2P determined by ICP-AES were 0.91 and 0.47, respectively. These results confirm that the CoP and Co2P catalysts with stoichiometric P/Co ratios are prepared by temperature-programmed reduction of the corresponding mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3 in H2. The structures of the two phosphide catalysts were well preserved after the HDS of DBT (Fig. 1), indicating that they are stable or will not transfer to other phases under the conditions employed in the present work. As revealed by TEM images (Fig. 2 A and C), the CoP and Co2P particles were heterogeneously distributed with average particle sizes of 160 and 180 nm, respectively. Accordingly, the specific surface areas of CoP (5.9 m2/g) and Co2P (5.5 m2/g), determined by N2 physisorption, were about equally small if the measurement error is considered. At higher resolution (Fig. 2B and D), the lattice fringes with interplane distances of 0.25 nm due to the (200) plane of CoP and 0.22 nm corresponding to the (121) plane of Co2P can be clearly observed. The CO uptakes of the CoP and Co2P catalysts were almost zero. Fig. 3 shows the XPS spectra of both the fresh and spent catalysts in the Co 2p, P 2p, and S 2p regions. For the fresh CoP catalyst, the major peak in the Co 2p region at 778.8 eV corresponds to the Co 2p3/2 peak of the reduced cobalt species in the CoP phase [32], while the predominant doublet in the P 2p region at ca. 129.5 and 130.3 eV can be attributed to the P species bonded to metal atoms in the form of phosphides [32–34]. The phosphorus 2p spectrum consists of two peaks due to spin–orbit interaction, with a separation of 0.8 eV [35]. However, as demonstrated by Barrie et al. [35], this doublet cannot be observed without monochromatization of the incident X-radiation. In the present work, monochromated Al Kα radiation was used for the XPS measurements, which allows the observation of the doublet. The peaks at higher binding energies are due to the cobalt oxides and PO4 3− species generated by air exposure of the phosphide catalysts before XPS measurement [32]. The Co 2p and P 2p spectra of the fresh Co2P catalyst were similar to those of CoP. The binding energies of the reduced cobalt (Coδ+) and phosphorus (Pδ−) species in Co2P were slightly lower and higher than those in CoP, respectively. The surface cobalt and phosphorus species in CoP and Co2P hardly changed after HDS reactions, except that the binding energies of the Pδ− species in the two spent catalysts and that of the Coδ+ species in the spent Co2P catalyst shifted to lower values. Sulfur was detected in the surface of the two spent catalysts. The S 2p spectra were characterized by a broad and asymmetric peak with peak maximum at 162.1 eV. Table 2 lists the surface and bulk atomic concentrations of Co, P, and S of the fresh and spent CoP and Co2P catalysts determined by XPS and ICP-AES, respectively. Although the CoP and Co2P catalysts possessed bulk P/Co ratios close to their stoichiometric ones, their surfaces were enriched in phosphorus. The surface atomic concentrations of phosphorus were above 82 at.% and the P/Co ratios were higher than 4.8. The surface cobalt concentration of the fresh Co2P catalyst (17.1 at.%) was only slightly higher than that of the fresh CoP catalyst (14.4 at.%). More sulfur was detected in the surface of the spent Co2P catalyst, and the incorporation of sulfur mainly led to a decrease in surface cobalt concentrations of the two phosphide catalysts. XPS can semi-quantitatively analyze surface composition, but both precision and accuracy suffer when the XPS peak intensity is small. The XPS spectra in the S 2p region showed low intensity peaks having low signal-to-noise, so there may be significant uncertainty on any atomic composition determined for sulfur in the spent Co2P and CoP catalysts. Hence, our analysis on the surface compositions of the cobalt phosphide catalysts is qualitative rather than quantitative. 3.2 HDS of DBT CoP was much more active than Co2P in the HDS of DBT (Fig. 4 ). The conversion of DBT over CoP at τ = 1.5 g·min/mol reached 61% (Fig. 4A), which was almost four times as high as that over Co2P (16%, Fig. 4C). BP and CHB were the two major products in the HDS of DBT over CoP (Fig. 4A). They were the most abundant products at τ < 0.74 g·min/mol and τ > 1.1 g·min/mol, respectively. TH-DBT was detected with low yield (Fig. 4A). The other minor products observed were HH-DBT, 1-PCHE, 3-PCHE, and bi(cyclohexane) (BCH) (Fig. 4A). The magnified Fig. 4 and the following figures can be found in the Supplementary Material (Figs. S1–S6). BP, CHB, and BCH all behaved like final products. Their yields increased with space–time (Figs. 4A and S1A in the Supplementary Material). The yields of TH-DBT, HH-DBT, 1-PCHE and 3-PCHE passed through maxima (Figs. 4A and S1A in the Supplementary Material), indicating that they are the intermediates of the HDS of DBT. The selectivities of CHB and BCH increased, whereas those of the other products decreased with space–time (Figs. 4B and S1B in the Supplementary Material). Over Co2P, BP and TH-DBT were the most and second most abundant products, respectively (Fig. 4C and D). The yields of all the products increased with space–time (Fig. 4C and S1C in the Supplementary Material), demonstrating that the HDS of DBT over Co2P is still in the initial stage of consecutive reaction. The selectivity-τ curves of Co2P differed from those of CoP mainly in that the selectivities of BP and HH-DBT were almost constant (cf. Figs. 4B and D, S1B and D in the Supplementary Material). Piperidine inhibited the HDS of DBT over both cobalt phosphides (Fig. 5 ). The yields of all products decreased after the addition of piperidine, and the formation of CHB was more inhibited than that of BP. The selectivity of BP in the presence of piperidine was higher than in the absence of piperidine, which mainly resulted from the decrease in CHB selectivity (cf. Figs. 4 and 5). The selectivity of TH-DBT, the other major product, was almost not affected by piperidine (cf. Figs. 4 and 5). No BCH was detected over Co2P at 0.25 kPa piperidine. 3.3 HDS of TH-DBT TH-DBT was more reactive than DBT. The conversions of TH-DBT over CoP and Co2P at τ = 1.5 g·min/mol were 84% and 56%, respectively (Fig. 6 A and C). The product distributions over the two catalysts were similar (Fig. 6). CHB, HH-DBT, and 1-PCHE were the three major products. Their yields decreased in the order CHB > HH-DBT > 1-PCHE. CHB was the predominant product. Its yield and selectivity increased with space–time. It also exhibited non-zero initial selectivity by extrapolating the selectivity-τ curves to τ = 0 (Fig. 6B and D). These results demonstrate that CHB is both a primary product and a final product in the HDS of TH-DBT. Both HH-DBT and 1-PCHE behaved like primary products and intermediates, as their yields passed through maxima and their selectivities decreased with space–time. DBT, 3-PCHE, 4-PCHE, BCH, and BP were all detected with low yields (Figs. 6 and S3 in the Supplementary Material). Piperidine showed different inhibiting effects on the HDS of TH-DBT over CoP and Co2P. The HDS of TH-DBT over CoP was less inhibited by piperidine than that over Co2P (Fig. 7 ). At τ = 1.5 g·min/mol, the conversions of TH-DBT over CoP (76%) and Co2P (36%) in the presence of 0.25 kPa piperidine were 8% and 20% lower than in the absence of piperidine, respectively (Fig. 7A and C). The product distribution over CoP was hardly affected by piperidine (cf. Figs. 6B, 7B, S3B and S4B in the Supplementary Material). Over Co2P, the yields of 1-PCHE and 3-PCHE increased while those of all the other products decreased after the addition of piperidine (cf. Figs. 6C and 7C). 1-PCHE became the most abundant product at τ < 0.74 g·min/mol (Fig. 7C). The inhibition of piperidine on the formation of CHB was particularly strong. At τ = 1.5 g·min/mol, the yield of CHB decreased markedly from 42% in the absence of piperidine to 19% in the presence of piperidine (Figs. 6C and 7C). 3.4 HDS of HH-DBT The reactivity of HH-DBT was high. The conversions of HH-DBT over CoP and Co2P at τ = 1.5 g·min/mol reached 97% and 79%, respectively (Fig. 8 A and C). It quickly dehydrogenated to TH-DBT. The other two major products observed were CHB and 1-PCHE. Over CoP, the yield of TH-DBT passed through a maximum at τ = 0.5 g·min/mol while its selectivity decreased with space–time (Fig. 8A and B), demonstrating that it is both an intermediate and a primary product. The yield and selectivity of CHB all increased with space–time. It became the most abundant product at τ > 0.74 g·min/mol (Fig. 8A and B). The differences in the product distributions between Co2P and CoP are as follows. (1) TH-DBT was the most abundant product over Co2P (Fig. 8C). Its yield increased with space–time (Fig. 8C), while its selectivity was almost constant under the present conditions (Fig. 8D). (2) The yield of CHB over Co2P (Fig. 8C) was much lower than over CoP (Fig. 8A), which was even lower than that of 1-PCHE at low space–time. It became the second most abundant product at τ > 0.74 g·min/mol (Fig. 8C). (3) The yield of 1-PCHE over Co2P passed through its maximum at space–time as high as 1.1 g·min/mol (Figs. 8C and S5C in the Supplementary Material). Over CoP, the yield of 1-PCHE already reached its maximum at τ < 0.25 g·min/mol (Figs. 8A and S5A in the Supplementary Material). The reaction of HH-DBT over CoP was only slightly inhibited by the addition of piperidine (Fig. 9 A). At τ = 1.5 g·min/mol, the conversion of HH-DBT over CoP in the presence of 0.25 kPa piperidine (93%, Fig. 9A) was only 4% lower than in the absence of piperidine (97%, Fig. 8A). However, the inhibition of piperidine on the conversion of HH-DBT over Co2P was strong. At τ = 1.5 g·min/mol and 0.25 kPa piperidine, the conversion of HH-DBT over Co2P (43%, Fig. 9C) was almost half of the value at 0 kPa piperidine (79%, Fig. 8C). Piperidine hardly affect the product selectivities of the HDS of HH-DBT over CoP (cf. Figs. 8B and 9B). Over Co2P, the selectivities of TH-DBT and CHB decreased, while those of phenylcyclohexenes (PCHEs) increased after the addition of piperidine (cf. Figs. 8D and 9D). 4 Discussion 4.1 Catalyst preparation The characterization results demonstrate that the reduction of the mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3 in H2 is a feasible method for the preparation of cobalt phosphides with stoichiometric P/Co ratios. Due to the covalent nature of the metal-rich transition-metal phosphides and monophosphides [15], the oxidation states of the metal and phosphorus species in these compounds are close to zero, as evidenced by XPS (Fig. 3). Hence, the precursors must be reduced so as to obtain the phosphide phases. The TPR of the phosphate precursors in flowing H2 proposed by Li et al. in 1998 [36] is the most commonly used method for the preparation of transition-metal phosphide catalysts. The reduction of Group VIII metal oxides usually occurs at relatively low temperatures. For instance, the CoO and Co3O4 powders were reduced to the hexagonal phase of Co metal at 350 and 250 °C, respectively [37]. The reduction of a NiO (100) crystal and NiO powders took place at temperatures ranging from 250 to 350 °C [38]. However, because the phosphorus atoms in phosphates possess the highest oxidation state (+5) and the PO bond is strong, the reduction of phosphate groups requires high temperature (generally higher than 500 °C) [19]. By means of synchrotron-based time-resolved X-ray diffraction, Rodriguez et al. [39] found that independent of the type of oxidic precursor, the formation of the metal phosphides (MoP, Ni2P, and MoNiP) occurred at temperatures between 600 and 800 °C. They suggested that the reduction of the phosphate groups was the final and determining step in the formation of the phosphide catalysts. At such high temperatures under H2, phosphorus loss may take place because of the generation and migration of volatile phosphorus species [39]. Therefore, the synthesis of some transition-metal phosphides by the conventional TPR method requires the use of excess phosphorus. This is particularly true for the preparation of Group VIII transition-metal phosphides. For instance, excess phosphorus has to be used for the preparation of Ni2P by temperature-programmed reduction of nickel phosphate precursors, otherwise metal-rich nickel phosphides like Ni12P5 with low HDS activities will be formed [40]. As already suggested by Cecilia et al. [25,26], because the oxidation state of the phosphorus atoms in phosphorous acid and phosphites is +3, they should be easier to reduce than the phosphate groups. Recently, Liu et al. [41] demonstrated that the disproportionation of phosphites took place at temperatures as low as ca. 360 °C, leading to the formation of PH3 (a strong reducing and phosphidation agent). All these factors may favor the formation of cobalt phosphides with stoichiometric P/Co ratios. Although the bulk CoP and Co2P catalysts were stoichiometrically prepared from the mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3, their surfaces were in a phosphorus-rich state (Table 2). A straightforward explanation can be the surface phosphorus enrichment due to the migration of reduced phosphorus atoms at high temperatures. Another possibility is that cobalt phosphides prefer to expose their phosphorus-rich planes. The lattice fringes observed in TEM images of CoP and Co2P correspond to the CoP (200) plane and the CoP (121) plane, respectively (Fig. 2B and D). The CoP (200) plane is terminated by phosphorus atoms, and the P/Co ratio of Co2P (121) plane (1) is also higher than the stoichiometric value (Fig. S7 in the Supplementary Material). Both P-terminated surfaces and surface P accumulation may account for the high surface P/Co values of the bulk CoP and Co2P catalysts. To clarify these important questions, further experimental and theoretical work is needed. 4.2 HDS At τ = 1.5 g·min/mol and 0 kPa piperidine, the conversion of DBT over CoP (61%, Fig. 4A) was not only much higher than that over Co2P (16%, Fig. 4C), but also higher than that over the other transition-metal phosphides under identical HDS reaction conditions (35% over a Ni2P catalyst prepared with a P/Ni molar ratio of 1.0 [27], 52% over a MoP catalyst [42], and 53% over a WP catalyst [28]). As far as the DBT conversion is concerned, CoP was the most active catalyst among these phosphides studied, while Co2P was the least active one. This seems to contradict a previous report that Ni2P, MoP, and WP were more active than CoP in DBT HDS and quinoline HDN [5]. As already mentioned in the Introduction section, cobalt phosphides were usually prepared by temperature-programmed reduction of cobalt phosphates in early studies, and large excess of phosphorus is needed to obtain phase-pure CoP. The excess phosphorus is known to have a strong negative influence on the HDS activities of transition-metal phosphides. In the present work, the CoP catalyst was stoichiometrically prepared from the mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3, which may explain its high HDS activity. Because the CO uptakes of CoP and Co2P were too low to be detected, we calculated the turnover frequencies (TOF) of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT over the two catalysts based on their specific surface areas and the conversions of these sulfur-containing molecules at the lowest space–time (0.25 g∙min/mol), and compared with those over WP [28]. WP adopts the same crystal structure as CoP and Co2P. (1) TOF = F 0 · X / w cat · S BET , where F 0 and X are the initial molar flow rate (μmol/s) and the conversion of the reactant, respectively; w cat represents the weight of the catalyst charged in g; SBET is the specific surface area of the catalyst in m2/g. The results are listed in Table 3 . The TOFs of DBT and its two hydrogenated intermediates over CoP in the absence of piperidine were higher than over WP and Co2P (Table 3 and Fig. S8 in the Supplementary Material). Although WP was more active than Co2P, it was more sensitive to piperidine inhibition [28]. The TOFs of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT over WP at 0.2 kPa piperidine were as low as those over Co2P at 0.25 kPa piperidine (Table 3). CoP exhibited a good nitrogen tolerability. The HDS of TH-DBT and HH-DBT over CoP was only slightly (TH-DBT) or moderately (HH-DBT) inhibited by the addition of 0.25 kPa piperidine (Table 3). These features make CoP with stoichiometric P/Co ratio a promising HDS catalyst. The initial selectivities of BP in the HDS of DBT over CoP (Fig. 4B) and Co2P (Fig. 4D) were estimated to be 50% and 51%, respectively, indicating that the direct desulfurization pathway (DDS) is as important as the hydrogenation pathway (HYD). The BP selectivity over CoP decreased with space–time, whereas that over Co2P was almost constant, suggesting that further reaction of BP occurs over CoP. We therefore carried out the hydrogenation of BP in the presence of 0.5 kPa benzothiophene over CoP and Co2P. The results demonstrated that hydrogenation of BP indeed took place over CoP with CHB as the dominant product, while the conversion of BP was almost zero over Co2P (Fig. S9 in the Supplementary Material). Apparently, CoP possesses higher hydrogenation activity than Co2P. It is known that the β-elimination of the cycloalkyl CS bond in HH-DBT yields 1-PCHE and 3-PCHE, and that the hydrogenation of PCHEs leads to the formation of CHB. This is consistent with our observations that 1-PCHE and 3-PCHE were the primary products and intermediates in the HDS of HH-DBT over the two cobalt phosphides (Figs. 8, 9, S5 and S6 in the Supplementary Material). CHB can be directly formed by the hydrogenolysis of HH-DBT as well, which explains its none-zero initial selectivity at τ = 0 g∙min/mol (Figs. 8 and 9). 1-PCHE behaved like a primary product in the HDS of TH-DBT (Figs. 6, 7, S3 and S4 in the Supplementary Material). This is expected because it can be directly formed by the hydrogenolysis of TH-DBT. CHB also exhibited the character of primary product with non-zero initial selectivity in the HDS of TH-DBT over the two cobalt phosphide catalysts (Figs. 6 and 7). This is unexpected if one assumes that the hydrogenolysis of the vinyl CS bond occurs prior to that of the aryl CS bond in TH-DBT. Under the circumstance, CHB should be the product of the hydrogenation of 1-PCHE, and thus should behave like a secondary product with zero initial selectivity. DBT and BP were detected with very low yields in the HDS of TH-DBT (Figs. 6 and 7) and HH-DBT (Figs. 8 and 9). In the HDS of TH-DBT, DBT is the product of the dehydrogenation of TH-DBT, and BP could be obtained by the hydrogenolysis of DBT. Nevertheless, the latter can be excluded under the present conditions, because these two compounds all behaved like primary products in the HDS of TH-DBT with non-zero initial selectivities (Figs. 6B, 7B, S3 and S4 in the Supplementary Material). Over Co2P in the presence of 0.25 kPa piperidine, the yield of BP was even higher than that of DBT (Fig. 7C and S4C in the Supplementary Material). In the HDS of HH-DBT over CoP and Co2P (Figs. 8, 9, S5 and S6 in the Supplementary Material), extrapolation to τ = 0 gave zero selectivity of DBT and non-zero selectivity of BP, suggesting that DBT and BP are the secondary and the primary products, respectively. In the HDS of HH-DBT over Co2P, the selectivity of DBT was zero at τ < 0.5 g∙min/mol in the absence of piperidine (Fig. 8D and S5D in the Supplementary Material) and DBT was not detected in the presence of 0.25 kPa piperidine (Figs. 9D and S6D in the Supplementary Material), but BP behaved like a primary product. All these results indicate that BP detected in the HDS of TH-DBT and HH-DBT cannot be the desulfurization product of DBT formed by the dehydrogenation of TH-DBT. BP could be the product of the disproportionation of PCHEs [27], but the yields of BP in the hydrogenation of 1-PCHE over CoP and Co2P at τ = 1.5 g∙min/mol were comparable to or even lower than those in the HDS of TH-DBT and HH-DBT under the identical conditions (Fig. S10 in the Supplementary Material). One explanation for these observations is that the aryl CS bonds in TH-DBT and HH-DBT are broken first to give 2-phenyl-l-cyclohexenethiol (2-PCHET, Scheme 1 a) and 2-phenylcyclohexanethiol (2-PCHT, Scheme 1b), respectively. 2-PCHET and 2-PCHT then undergo dehydrogenation and desulfurization to BP. CHB can be formed by the hydrogenolysis and hydrogenation of 2-PCHET, or the hydrogenolysis of 2-PCHT under H2 atmosphere (Scheme 1). These two intermediates were not detected in the HDS products, suggesting that they are very reactive under the present conditions. A similar mechanism was proposed by Sun and Prins in their mechanistic studies of the HDS of DBT over a Co-Mo/γ–Al2O3 sulfide catalyst [43]. Our recent results demonstrated that 2-PCHT is able to undergo dehydrogenation and fast desulfurization reactions to yield BP over Ni2P, MoP, and WP [44]. Based on the product distributions and above discussion, we propose the reaction network of the HDS of DBT over the two cobalt phosphide catalysts (Scheme 2 ). For a quantitative comparison of the catalytic performances of CoP and Co2P, we studied the kinetics of the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT. The regression analysis indicates that the kinetics of the HDS of DBT and TH-DBT over CoP can be well fitted by a first-order rate model with correlation coefficients R2 higher than 0.99 (Fig. S11 in the Supplementary Material). Due to the high conversion of HH-DBT over CoP at τ > 0.74 g∙min/mol both at 0 and 0.25 kPa piperidine (above 83%, Figs. 8A and 9A), good fits were obtained only at low space–time (τ < 0.74 g∙min/mol) (Fig. S11 in the Supplementary Material). The rate equation of the pseudo-first-order model for a plug-flow reactor is: (2) - ln 1 - X = k · τ , where k is the rate constant (mol·g−1·min−1). −ln(1 − X) is then plotted against τ, and the rate constant k can be determined from the slope of each fitted line. Over Co2P, the concentrations of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT were found to decrease almost linearly with space–time both in the absence and presence of piperidine (Figs. 4C–9C), suggesting that all the HDS reactions over Co2P may follow pseudo-zero-order kinetics: (3) X = ( k / p 0 ) · τ , where p 0 is the initial partial pressure of the reactant in kPa. When the conversions of reactants were plotted against space–time for the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT over Co2P at 0 and 0.25 kPa piperidine, good linear relationships were observed (Fig. S12 in the Supplementary Material). To further verify this assumption, we increased the initial partial pressure of DBT from 1 kPa to 1.9 kPa. As expected, the conversion of DBT increased linearly with space–time and the slope decreased proportionally from 0.114 to 0.053 (Fig. S13 in the Supplementary Material). The pseudo-zero-order kinetics suggests strong adsorption of DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates on Co2P. The calculated concentration-τ curves of the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT from the obtained rate constants based on the pseudo-first-order (CoP) and the pseudo-zero-order (Co2P) models are shown in Figs. S14 and S15 in the Supplementary Material, respectively. In consistence with regression analysis, the experimental data agreed well with the calculated concentration-τ curves. The total reaction constants of the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT are summarized in Table 4 . The rate constants of all the steps in the reaction network were calculated from the total rate constants and the initial product selectivities estimated by extrapolating the selectivity-τ curves to τ = 0 (Scheme 2). The kinetic analysis confirms that the DDS pathway of the HDS of DBT is as important as the HYD pathway over the two cobalt phosphide catalysts. The dehydrogenation of HH-DBT to TH-DBT was the fastest step (2.833 over CoP and 0.361 over Co2P), while the fully hydrogenation of HH-DBT to dodecahydro-dibenzothiophene (DH-DBT) and the subsequent desulfurization of DH-DBT to BCH was the slowest one (0.008 over CoP and 0.006 over Co2P). The rate constants of the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT to BP were almost equal. These two steps were only faster than the desulfurization of HH-DBT to BCH. The rate constants of all steps in the HDS network of DBT over CoP (Scheme 2a) were much higher than the corresponding steps over Co2P (Scheme 2b). The total desulfurization rate constants of DBT and its two hydrogenated intermediates (excluding all the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation steps) over CoP at 0 kPa piperidine decreased in the order DBT (0.318) < TH-DBT (0.666) < HH-DBT (0.789) (Scheme 2a). Over Co2P, the order became DBT (0.058) < HH-DBT (0.182) < TH-DBT (0.211) (Scheme 2b). The desulfurization rate of HH-DBT was even slightly lower than that of TH-DBT over Co2P. Such an order could be due to the strong adsorptions of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT on Co2P, as suggested by their pseudo-zero-order kinetics. Thiophenic compounds could adsorb in both flat and perpendicular modes. Previous DFT calculations [45] demonstrated that over a Mo10S18 cluster, the adsorption energies of DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates in the flat adsorption configuration decreased with the degree of hydrogenation. This has been adopted by Wang and Prins to explain the different reaction orders observed in the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT over a sulfided Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [46]. They found that the reaction of DBT and TH-DBT was between first and zero order and that of HH-DBT was first order, which was in line with the aromaticity of these sulfur-containing molecules. DBT and TH-DBT were more aromatic than HH-DBT, and thus their adsorption was stronger. In the case of perpendicular adsorption over a Mo10S18 cluster, however, the hydrogenated intermediates showed higher adsorption energies than DBT [45]. This is probably because that the perpendicular adsorption depends mainly on the binding strength of the S–Mo bond, which would benefit from the increase of electron density on sulfur. The analysis of Mulliken charges of DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates demonstrated that the positive charge of the sulfur atom decreased with the degree of hydrogenation, indicating electron density gain over the hydrogenated derivatives. The reason can be that sulfur atoms in the hydrogenated intermediates of DBT regain a portion or all of its electrons previously contributed to the π system of the thiophene ring [45]. Hence, it is possible that DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT are mainly perpendicularly adsorbed on the surface of Co2P through sulfur atoms prior to desulfurization reactions. The perpendicular adsorption of HH-DBT is too strong, therefore its desulfurization rate constant is even lower than that of TH-DBT. The desulfurization of HH-DBT over the two cobalt phosphide catalysts occurred mainly through β-elimination to 1-PCHE and 3-PCHE, which was about 2.5 (over CoP) or 2.9 (over Co2P) times as fast as the hydrogenolysis of HH-DBT to CHB (Scheme 2). Nevertheless, CoP and Co2P behaved differently in the desulfurization of TH-DBT. Over CoP, the desulfurization of TH-DBT to CHB (0.350) was faster than the hydrogenolysis of TH-DBT to PCHEs (0.296); whereas the rate constant of the former step (0.046) was only one third of that of the later step (0.156) over Co2P. If our assumption for the direct formation of CHB from TH-DBT (Scheme 1a) holds true, the cleavage of the aryl CS bond of TH-DBT over CoP must be faster than the hydrogenolysis of its vinyl CS bond. Over Co2P, the hydrogenolysis of TH-DBT to PCHEs (or the hydrogenolysis of the vinyl CS bond of TH-DBT) was the fastest among all the desulfurization steps (Scheme 2b). Piperidine strongly inhibited the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions among DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates as well as the DDS of DBT to BP (Scheme 2), but its negative influence on the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT were much less pronounced (Scheme 2). Piperidine inhibited the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT over CoP and Co2P in different manners. Over CoP, the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT to CHB was more inhibited by piperidine than that to PCHEs (Scheme 2a). Particularly, the β-elimination of HH-DBT to PCHEs was not influenced by piperidine. The situation was reversed over Co2P (Scheme 2b). Piperidine mainly inhibited the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT to PCHEs, whereas the desulfurization of these intermediates to CHB was not affected (HH-DBT) or even slightly accelerated (TH-DBT) by the addition of 0.25 kPa piperidine. All these results suggest that the active sites of the two cobalt phosphide catalysts cannot be the same. Our present data are not sufficient enough to allow an in-depth discussion on the structure-performance relationships of CoP and Co2P. The compositions of the two phosphides are different, but they adopt the same orthorhombic structure belonging to the Pnma space group [47]. The electronic structures of Co2P and CoP differ from each other. Yang et al. [47] studied the structural stability and electronic properties of several cobalt phosphides by first-principle calculations based on density functional theory. Their results suggested charge transfers from Co basins to P basins. They found that each P atom obtained 0.60 e− from Co atoms for Co2P and 0.35 e− from Co atoms for CoP, which means that CoP is more covalent or less ionic than Co2P. WP also crystalizes in the orthorhombic Pnma space group. According to the available data, the charge transfer in WP was 0.56 e− [48]. This value is between those of CoP and Co2P, and the TOFs of DBT and its two hydrogenated intermediates over WP at 0 kPa piperidine were also in between (Table 3). We therefore plotted these TOFs against the charge transfer numbers of CoP, Co2P, and WP, and reasonable linear relationships were all observed (Fig. S16 in the Supplementary Material). The TOFs decreased with the increase in the charge transfer numbers of the three phosphide catalysts. Hence, the electronic structure or the degree of covalency can be an important factor determining the activities of transition-metal phosphides with the same crystal structure. However, such a relation is invalid for transition-metal phosphide catalysts with different structures. No relation between TOFs of the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT and charge transfer numbers of the phosphide catalysts was observed if the data of the MoP catalysts (the charge transfer in MoP was 1.06 e− [48], and the TOFs were calculated based on our previous results [42]) were added (Fig. S16 in the Supplementary Material), suggesting that the HDS performances of transition-metal phosphides are affected by multiple factors. It has been established that the surfaces of Ni2P, MoP, and WP are partially sulfided to form surface phosphosulfide phases during HDS reactions, while their bulk structures are maintained [34,49–51]. This is also the case for CoP and Co2P. Only diffraction lines due to phosphide phases were observed in the XRD patterns of the fresh and spent catalysts (Fig. 1), while sulfur was detected in the surfaces of the spent catalysts (Fig. 3B). The S 2p XPS spectra of the spent CoP and Co2P catalysts were in agreement with those of the spent Ni2P, MoP, and WP catalysts [34,50,51], confirming the formation of cobalt phosphosulfide phases during HDS reactions. The asymmetric line-shape of the S 2p peaks suggests the existence of multiple sulfur species, but their low intensities do not allow an analysis. This agrees with previous work that more than one kind of sulfur species may be present in the phosphosulfide phases [33,44,52]. The XPS atomic concentrations of sulfur in CoP and Co2P were as low as 5.9 at.% and 8.0 at.%, respectively (Table 2), which is in consistent with the reports by Burns et al. [18] and Cecilia et al. [26] that Co2P captured more sulfur on the surface than CoP. For both catalysts, the presence of sulfur mainly led to significant decreases in the cobalt concentrations, whereas the decreases in the phosphorus concentrations were minor (Table 2), suggesting that sulfur mainly replaces metal species to form cobalt phosphosulfide phases. It is possible that sulfur adsorbs (or interacts) more strongly with Co, rather than P, hence covering it preferentially. In our previous study [53], we prepared a Ni2P/MCM-41 catalyst, a Group VIII transition-metal phosphide catalyst, with stoichiometric Ni/P ratio by using a H2 plasma reduction method, and passivated the catalyst either by 10.0 vol% H2S/H2 or 1.0 vol% O2/He. Similarly, we found by means of X-ray absorption spectroscopy that H2S mainly reacted with Ni–Ni sites of Ni2P. The sulfidation behavior of WP, a Group VIB transition-metal phosphide, was different. In the HDS of DBT, sulfur mainly replaced phosphorous species to form tungsten phosphosulfide phase [34]. 5 Conclusions CoP and Co2P were prepared by temperature-programmed reduction of the mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3 with stoichiometric P/Co ratios, but the XPS results suggest that their surfaces were still enriched in phosphorus. CoP was much more active than Co2P in the HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT. It was even more active than WP. CoP was also more tolerant to piperidine poisoning than Co2P. These features make CoP a promising HDS catalyst. Over the two cobalt phosphide catalysts, the DDS pathway and the HYD pathway of DBT HDS were about equally important. Based on product distributions, a reaction network of DBT HDS over CoP and Co2P was proposed. CHB and BP were found to be primary products in the HDS of TH-DBT and HH-DBT, suggesting that the cleavage of the aryl CS bonds in TH-DBT and HH-DBT can occur prior to the cleavage of the vinyl CS bond in TH-DBT and the cycloalkyl CS bond in HH-DBT. The desulfurization of HH-DBT over CoP and Co2P occurred mainly through β-elimination, but the two catalysts behaved differently in the desulfurization of TH-DBT. The HDS of DBT, TH-DBT, and HH-DBT followed a pseudo-first-order kinetics over CoP, whereas those over Co2P can be described by a pseudo-zero-order kinetics. This suggests strong adsorptions of DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates over Co2P. The electronic structure or the degree of covalency can be an important factor determining the activities of the cobalt phosphide catalysts. Piperidine strongly inhibited the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions and the DDS of DBT to BP. Its negative influence on the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT were much less pronounced. The active surfaces of CoP and Co2P in HDS reactions were phosphosulfide phases. The sulfur contents in these sulfur-containing phases were low. It is likely that sulfur mainly replaced cobalt to form the cobalt phosphosulfide phases. coredata.dc:description: CoP and Co2P were prepared by temperature-programmed reduction of the mixtures of Co(OH)2 and H3PO3 with stoichiometric P/Co ratios, but their surfaces were still enriched in phosphorus. Based on the product distributions of the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT), 1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-dibenzothiophene (TH-DBT), and 1,2,3,4,4a,9b-hexahydro-dibenzothiophene (HH-DBT), a reaction network of DBT HDS was proposed and the mechanisms of the cleavage of different CS bonds in DBT and its hydrogenated intermediates were discussed. CoP was much more active and more nitrogen-tolerant than Co2P, which make it a promising HDS catalyst. The HDS reactions over CoP and Co2P followed a pseudo-first-order kinetics and a pseudo-zero-order kinetics, respectively. Piperidine strongly inhibited the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions and the direct desulfurization of DBT, but its inhibition on the desulfurization of TH-DBT and HH-DBT were less pronounced. The active surfaces of CoP and Co2P in HDS reactions can be cobalt phosphosulfide phases.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene and its hydrogenated intermediates over bulk CoP and Co2P catalysts with stoichiometric P/Co ratios
